reviewText:
Take the traditional roguelike formula - randomized characters, dungeon layouts, items, stat systems, one life, etc.

Take the traditional tower defense formula - turn based income, defensive towers, waves of enemies.

Add a dash of a party based RPG into the mix.

Combine them together? You have Dungeon of the Endless.

Clever usage of your available resources is a must if you seek to come out on top, and any little mistake can very well cost you the playthrough. Simple in concept, deceptively tough in execution. It's the manacala of computer games. It took me 26 attempts before my first victory!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I havent expected much from this game and it exeeded all my expectations. Classic turn of all rouge like/lite games was replaced with opening a door. Every time you open any door you receive access to next room. Room can contain different bonuses or monsters. You need DUST to power new rooms. But you have never enough of it to power all rooms at once and every unpowered room can spawn squad of monsters every time you open the door. The more unpowered rooms you have the more monsters can come. So you need to (despite of random nature of labyrinth) plan your advance and do whatever it takes to not allow monsters to owerwhelm you. Once you have found an exit from dungeon you need to transport your power crystal towards it. When you start to moove your crystal rooms start to loose power and monsters start to spawn with extreme rate. So once you have started mooving crystal - time working against you so you need to escape the level as soon as you can.

Main disadvantage - multiplayer is not ready yet.
Main Advantage - haven't encountered any bugs yet. No bugs at all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The last patch for this title, as of this writing, was 0.5.2, so things may have changed as you read this review.

Even if things have changed however, this is still a very solid recommendation. I had this game on my wishlist from the first time I saw it, and struggled with whether to get it or not as I have been burned by other Early Access titles before. But this game blends several genres together beautifully; roguelike (or roguelite, depending on how picky you are at naming it) along with tower defense and turned based role-playing.

The story is pretty barebones at this point; you're on a prison ship, and it gets shut down and overrun by monsters, and thus you have to escape. For some reason that isn't explained, you need to take a crystal (presumably a power source?) with you. The crystal serves as your base" hit points

reviewText: Dungeon of the Endless is a really kickass RPG/rogue-like Dungeon-Defense game. It's very fun with multiple people but there are a few issues, you see, to unlock a character (even in multiplayer) you have to hold that character in your control for 3 floors after finding them, but only you unlock them. The only other issue I've had is that every time we get to around Floor 10-12 the game auto-crashes or will freeze, or the elevator simply wont trigger, so at this current point it is unwinnable for me or my friends. Maybe we're the only ones with this issue, but i've come to doubt that. Other than the previous listed issues, Dungeon of the Endless, like its' other games, kicks total ♥♥♥, fun gameplay, cool items (and item descriptions) cool characters with great backstories, good OST, and most of all, Endless Fun.

reviewText:
Dungeon of the Endless, to put it simply, does everything right.

At its heart, Dungeon of the Endless is a relatively generic hero-based tower defense game. You defend your core node against spawning armies of increasing difficulty while building modules to defend and support your heroes. If this was all Dungeon of the Endless was, it would really just be another Kongregate tower defense game.

However, the mechanic that Amplitude chose to focus their core gameplay on is exploration, and what a glorious implementation it is.  I've always been a fan of games that use exploration as a resource mechanic. I enjoy puzzle games and this one simple mechanic can turn nearly any game into thought-provoking puzzler.

The premise of the game is simple. You're on a ship and you crash land. The only thing salvageable from your ship is a power source. You need to protect this power source and drag it through each of the levels until you reach the top and can be rescued.

Of course, it's not that simple.

Dungeon of the Endless uses a resource system comprised of industry (for building things), science (for learning how to build things), and food (for keeping your dudes alive and leveling up). You gain these resources by opening doors (exploration). There is also a concept of Dust as a resource, which you find in some rooms or from some monsters.

By allocating Dust, you can light up different rooms in the level. Lighting up rooms does a few things: powers your devices in the room and prevents monsters from spawning. However, you don't have enough Dust to light every room, so it becomes a puzzle of what rooms to light up and/or occupy to minimize the spawning enemies.

When you do find the level's exit and you plan to try to move your power source to it, the fun truly happens. From every dark room, enemies constantly spawn. The person carrying the crystal moves at half speed, so it's up to everyone else to defend that person until they reach the exit and your team can leave the level.

Speaking of your team, you start with two dudes. They all have different abilities and different stats. Over the course of the game, you can use food to level up your guys (up to a max of level 15) which helps their stats, gives them new abilities, etc.

All of these concepts work completely and are executed flawlessly. There is a sense of constant panic and dread when you're exploring, particularly when you're short on resources or dust. You want to spend resources to improve your team, but want to save some for emergencies.

If I have a complaint about the game is that it's a bit too easy. Once you understand the fundamentals of the game and have a good strategy, it pays to just keep repeating that strategy for the entire game. However, the developers very intelligently added a variety of ships that change the rules of the game. This is where the future challenge lies.

One of the best titles in recent memory. Well worth the low price.

reviewText:
So remember those other two games that this dev studio made that were super innovative that I like a lot?

This is like those games and not like those games. It's like them in that it's super innovative. It's not like them in almost (I say again almost) every other respect.

This is kind of a dungeon crawl. And kind of a tower defense. It has elements of turn based and real time strategy involved. It's kind of funny but can be kind of tense and serious. It has a perfectly winning single player and a perfectly winning multiplayer that are virtually identical and don't suffer at all from this. Every choice might matter and it might not matter at all when the next door opens. You can probably play through a few sessions in ten minutes and have a perfectly good time or agonize over a campaign for hours, even yelling at friends in VOIP the whole time. You kind of want to screw around with this game and you kind of want to take it seriously and beat it, because it is quite simply very difficult and simultaneously very fun.

For Amplitude: I am sold. Really, just keep up quality like this and I will tell you to shut up and take my money every time. You guys are amazing and I really hope everything goes well for you for this and any other project you guys work on.

TL,DR- Buy this, play it, have fun, there is literally no reason not to.

reviewText:
Basically the video game version of Closing Time by Semisonic

-Your goal is to open all the doors up and let yourself out into the world
-Its a strategic advantage to turn on all the lights over every boy and every girl
-You may not get the option of going home, but you can't stay here
-You gather up jackets (prison uniforms and the like)
-You move to the exits (with the crystal)
-You hope that you've found a friend (because you'll probably die if you don't have a full party)
-Every new beginning comes from some other beginning's end (permadeath)
-Both are related to alcoholism (trust me on this, just give it some time)

The big difference between this game and Closing Time is that in Dungeon of the Endless, the hits keep on coming! (please don't strangle me, just buy the game because it's good)

reviewText:
This game has the ability to make time pass very fast. I'm thankful to the pirating community for being able to try this gem of a game before I bought it. I don't have the best computer so it's a gamble to purchase games, and living in a small town without any place to work has made game purchasing hard as of late. So when I was working I made sure to pick this one up to have support the authors. That's something all of you should do, if you pirate a game and enjoy it, then buy it!
Anyway, this game is best described as a tower defence roguelike dungeon crawler. I'm not always in the tower defense mood, but when I am I am glad to have this game to go to. My only grief is the same grief I have with most tower defense games. Once you figure out a working strategy the challenge vanishes. Thankfully there are other game modes to play with, some of which don't allow me to do my winning strategy. (Boy did my heart sink once I figured out the strategy to just breeze through the game though)
I recently got caught up in a nearly 16 hour straight gaming session with this one (which is when I figured out my strategy) and got a little burnt out and probably wont be playing it again for some time. I'm still glad to have it in my library and if any further updates come alone to freshen things up a bit more I'll certainly hop back into it.
Oh, and one more grief is the online play. It's best to play with friends that you know already and to communicate using skype or something. I've never finished to the end on any online play, someone almost always drops out after the second floor, if not the host dropping everyone immediately after game start. I once made it to the eighth floor with someone online. But what started with 4 became 2 after the third floor. If there was a way for the resources to be divided up among the players or something different than the current system it would help a lot. I've had games that quit immediately because someone used up a resource right away or built a module that made the host upset. All and all, unless you have friends like I said before, just don't worry about the multiplayer.
In all if anything I wrote sounds appealing then go for it! Especially if it's on sale. I really need to stop getting inspired to write a review right before I go to bed. I've been nodding off while writing this and forgetting what I just wrote. So sorry if this is a bit jumbled. It was written by a very sleepy man who for some reason, decided now is the time to share with the world that I like this game! Keep up the good work game making team guys who made this!

reviewText:
WARNING: So here we are, Dungeon of the Endless. A very different game from Amplitude studios; who specialized in 4X games (Endless Space, Endless Legend). And while this game has multiple elements of those previous games and 4X games in general, if you are looking for a 4X Game, this is not your pickup. If you are looking for a good rogue-like, a good tower defense game, or a mix of both and some 4X elements, this is the best pickup for you on the market.






Settings: The settings are useful and helpful, as everyone has their own preferences. Overall positive. This goes for the UI of the game as well.

Story: There is little direct story in this game, such as in The Binding of Isaac, but much is hidden in the lore and different unlocks you find in the game. These will not be further discussed, because spoilers.

Gameplay: Time for the meat of this review. The gameplay is relatively simple. Your characters progress through rooms on twelve different floors, each floor progressing in difficulty. There is always a chance for monsters to spawn, and you will fight them. But the big part of the game is the four major resources that come into play. Here they are:
Industry (Gear Icon): Industy is used to build things (notably modules): They can generate other resources, or defend rooms.
Science: Spend science to research new modules.
Food: Levels up/heals your heroes.
Dust: Does not generate per floor, but is picked up. Used to light rooms.
If a room is not lit, monsters might spawn in that room. So yeah. You're going to need some defenses. There is a crystal in the starting room, once you find the exit, you must take that crystal to the exit. You can't leave until the character CARRYING the crystal enters it. Once the crystal is picked up, in every dark room monsters will spawn.

Elements: The rogue-like element is pretty obvious. The 4X elements of resource management and production, and how to spend them is super important. But tower defense is pretty simple. Build things that help heroes, or hurt monsters, so that they can't get to your crystal. When the crystal is hit, you lose dust. When the crystal dies, you lose. When all the heroes die, you lose.

Difficulty: It is an odd game in difficulty. At the start, there are two difficulties: Too easy and Easy. Too easy after a few games to get the hang of things becomes too easy. Easy is brutal, and requires you to scrap for resources, mangage them incredibly well, and then most likely die to some fatass punching your crystal.

Replayability: Yes. It has proceduraly generated floors. And it's a rogue-like. Never heard of a good rouge-like without replayability.

Conclusion: This game isn't often what people are looking for, especially fans of previous games by Amplitude. But this is a fantastic blend of multiple genres, including the dying tower defense games, and the somewhat bland 4X games. This revitalizes these elements in a unique blend that requires the player to be smart, quick to adapt to situations, good with spending resources and leveling the hero, which brings some RPG into the game, and not getting too frustrated when that fatass kills your crystal three games in a row because you didn't upgrade those claymoar mines on floor seven to get a HUD module that no matter what you do keeps getting destroyed halfway through the floor because you haven't saved up enough industry or science to buy or research better protection, and now one of your heroes is dead because there wasn't enough food to heal her, and oh my god it's Midnight. I need to sleep. Well maybe let's have one more go.

reviewText:
Dungeon of the Endless is a top-down roguelike dungeon exploration & tower defense game with many unlockable elements set in the Endless game universe.

The player uses a squad of up to 4 characters to explore a multi-floor dungeon one room at a time while protecting a power crystal. Like other Endless games, the four resources are Food, Industry, Dust, and Science (FIDS). With each door opened, more FIDS accumulate, but dangerous monsters may spawn. Players eventually discover a dungeon floor exit and carry the crystal to a new dungeon floor, continuing on until the game ends at the 12th floor.

Characters may be discovered in-game and unlocked after completing a certain number of floors with that character. Characters have different strengths as might be expected, including attack power, defense, movement speed, and wit"
date: which in this game translates into better module operation bonuses. Certain secret combinations of characters lead to different in-game events.\n\nFood
hoursPlayed: and Science increase in a predictable fashion with each door opened
voteText: but Dust is less predictable and cannot be saved between levels. Dust may sometimes be discovered in new rooms or obtained after defeating monsters.\n\nRooms adjacent to the crystal may be powered (or "lit") subject to a limit based on the current amount of Dust. Lit rooms do not spawn monsters. Given enough industry

votesTotal:
and different rooms have different limits for "minor modules".

Items may be discovered in new rooms and are bought and sold for FIDS at merchants which may be discovered in new rooms.

A special Research module may appear in a new room

Early Access Review

Great game, still in Alpha.

Overall, you can see where the developers are taking this game and even prior to Beta, this game is addicting. It has some great resource management and RPG elements.

Want a Tower Defense Game? Check.
Want a RPG where you can level characters and find equipment for them? Check.
Want a resource management strategy game? Check
Want a puzzle game where you need to figure out which door you want to walk through next? Check.

Basically, get this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What a wonderful roguelike comboed with tower defense.  Even in Alpha this is as stable and playable as Endless Space was on release.  Amplitude had my trust after Endless Space which is why I risked an Alpha purchase.  Not disappointed.

You start with two heroes.  They have skills, inventory and slots of weapon/armour/tool.  Each room you clear gives you the next wave of resources which you can use to level your heroes, build or research.  You can have your heroes man stations that you build in each room to vary your resource income if you can do without them.  So you have to manage your heroes and incoming enemies.  That's the basics of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most people that enjoy FTL will enjoy this.

In FTL the thrill is getting to the next beacon. Seeing what the game throws at you, and trying your best to handle it
In DoTE? What's behind the next door? If the proposition of sick anticipation for the next sadistic amalgam of chaos that you might find behind that door excites your inner masochist then this is the game for you!

Dungeon of the Endless is an immaculate blend of genres---so much so that it feels like something brand new.
The consortium of rpg elements, tower defense, procedurally generatred levels, and tower defense are all wrapped superbly in Amplitude's signature UI. Speaking of the UI it is sleek, clean, cripse, and effectively delivers you all the information required seemlessly.

While the game is far from complete there is more than enough difficutly and challenge involved. A meaty roster of characters and several difficult floors to plow through. The randomly generated nature offers much replayability, all the while Amplitude contineously injects more content!

reviewText:
Dungeon of the Endless is another entry in Amplitude's loosely connected Endless Universe. The game combines roguelike elements with the dungeon crawler.

The premise is this: you are among the handful of survivors remaining after a penal transport ship was attacked. Your escape pod crashes into the bowels of Auriga, a planet that's a wonderous hybrid of fantasy and science fiction, Our heroes must tow their escape pod's energy crystal up to the surface, floor by floor, in order to survive.

Players accomplish this trek by opening dungeon doors. This is where the game gets its turn-by-turn basis from, as each door counts for one turn. The turn aspect is central, as the vast majority of your resources will be generated in between turns from various resource modules you'll construct. Of course, opening any given door has a chance of spawning waves of enemies which the player must fend off in an effort to protect the energy crystal. If the energy crystal reaches zero, it's game over.

If this sounds like a familiar mechanic, that's because it is. It's the epitome of the tower defense game and you'll find that there is a plethora of offensive, defensive, and supportive modules the player can research and construct to assist in the effort. As in other tower defense games, each of the many enemy types have different priorities and abilities, so strategic use of these modules is important. Simply slamming down the default turret gun isn't going to help you (and in at least one game mode isn't even an option).

The goal of each level is to find the exit elevator. When the player finally finds it, they will have to plan for an anxiety-fueled escort mission. One of the heroes must transport the crystal to the exit elevator. Once the crystal is picked up, endless waves of enemies will begin spawning in darkened rooms. To make matters worse, whoever is carrying the crystal will essentially be out of commission for the battle, as bearing the crystal creates a tremendous speed debuff and disables attacks and abilities for that character. Once the crystal makes it to the elevator, the player may leave. Be careful, however, as it is possible to leave without your other party members and they will subsequently be removed from the party.

Along with the variety of modules, we have a variety of characters each with different abilities and perks. Each character belongs to one of three factions: crew members, prisoners, or natives. This is a background element but it does affect some perks and stat growth. For example, natives are the cheapest to level up but their stats aren't really impressive in their early levels. In this respect, the game is very much like an RPG, as most characters seem more easily fitted toward one role due to their stat growth and abilities. For instance, characters with a high Speed stat make suitable crystal runners because the effects of the aforementioned debuff will be less noticeable.

The graphics use a pixel aesthetic, although it does not feel retro in style. It has a crisp feel to it and is pleasing to the eyes. Despite the simplicity, Amplitude has managed to create an interesting diversity of environments. Indeed, all the rooms are invariably boxy, but it's clear they put some work into trying to make the floors feel different. There's an actual sense of progress across geographic space by using different artistic themes for the decor.

The sound quality is excellent. However, while the soundtrack is fantastic you may find it a bit repetitive after a few hours of play. I found myself turning the music off and turning on other sources for background noise after some time.

Finally, the way in which this game unravels its lore is extremely subtle and I love it. Small vignettes explaining unseen stories can occur between levels, but only if you have the appropriate characters in your party. These stories can be simply amusing, explain what a character is all about, or inform on the relationships between our starring cast. The coolest thing about these is that each story ends in a buff being granted to those involved, empowering you for the floors ahead.

Overall, I recommend this game enthusiastically. It's a wonderful blend of many different game mechanics that somehow seems to work. However, one final warning to any potential buyers: this game is difficult at first. Do not be fooled by the two options of Easy and Too Easy. I recommend chewing on Too Easy at first until you get the hang of the game. Some events are high risk/high reward and the choice of whether to take that risk is best served by a judgment cultivated in the crucible of Dungeon of the Endless.

reviewText: This game is hard, relentless, unforgiving, incredibly fun, addictive and has tons of replayability.  I personally think this game is a hard to learn, hard to master type game.  This game is not for the weak-willed who seek handholding, checkpoints or walks in the park.\n\nDungeon of the Endless is a tower defence game that draws RPG, rogue-like, dungeon crawling and resource management elements.  You start each game by picking 2 heroes out of a 24 (with all of DLC and unlockable characters) member cast.  Each hero has different stats that help your team in one way or another (Speed, Power, Health, and Wit).  Your objective is to look for the exit of the floor, which leads to the next floor.  Each floor gets progressively harder and harder the further down you go.  To win" or complete the game

reviewText:
Just picked this up on the Holiday Sale.

I've been a big fan of Amplitudes games for awhile now, having spent a whole bunch of time with Endless Space and not enough time with Endless Legend. Their games are clean, polished, and they've done a wonderful job of world building with the whole Endless thing.

Only one session down with DotE so far and I know I'm going to be hooked. I'm a sucker for tower defence games but the way in which they put together this game has brought the genre to a new level. Great design, both gameplay and visually, make this stand out for me. I look forward to spending many, many hours with this title.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Loving this game so far. I have both Endless Space and Endless Legend, and I think they both show promise, but ultimately aren't quite 'there' yet. But with this game, they've taken the world, the lore, and the feel, as well as some of the concepts (resources) and applied them in a VERY different package. This is part RPG, part tower defence, all fun!

Graphics style works, and the game has a feel that is reminiscent of the wonderful iPad game - Sword & Sworcery. Pixel graphics that really work, a wonderful, atmospheric soundtrack. Really solid.

And the game play is wonderful (albeit hard - i'm playing on the easiest setting and still finding it a real challenge to get a decent strategy). You'll need to be a little patient, but use those defences and you'll get there.

A wonderful example of how a simple concept, well executed, can be delightfully engaging. Well done dev team, well done!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game just proves that you don't need a powerful graphic engine to make a potentially great game. The interface is intuitive and the style is rich enough to give you an artgasm.

The game itself has a fairly easy objective - get your dust-filled crystal thing to an exit. But don't be fooled by the simplicity, the game can be punishing. When you take the crystal out of its notch, be prepared to face continous waves of enemies. It's difficult in a sense that it'll force you to utilize anything at your disposal in favor of just making a run for it. It's a game that will test your attention as well as your ability to make tough strategic choices.

If you're sick and tired of shooters, consider picking up this game. It's colorful, easy to pick up and incredibly easy on the eyes.

reviewText:
As a recent release, I  have found this to be my favourite game so far this month, the gameplay is unique, and a good combination of genres.
The music is wonderful, the characters are different and offer a variety of combinations of skills.

The only negative thing I'd have to say about this game is the multiplayer, at times can be very unstable. If this is fixed in any coming updates I'd have no complaints about this game. The difficulty is just right, and rewarding and I can't wait to see if we get even more brutal difficulties to truly test our sanity and endurance.

Some would say the dust generation is unbalanced, but I find it just right, of having to choose between fully exploring or just blizting it before i lose any (more) characters.

To any of my friends who even reads this, you totally gotta get it for such a cheap game.

reviewText:
An enjoyable RTS / Tower Defense / RPG hybrid with roguelike elements that will sink in your head for days. The gameplay is original, yet extremely challenging even on the lowest difficulty, the art-style is gorgeous and minimalistic, and there is tons of content just thrown at you at every turn. It's also story-lite so there's no walls of text thrown at you constantly.
The game has a steep enough learning curve, only giving you a short tutorial on the basics, requiring you to figure out things for yourself.
You start with two heroes, but eventually you will unlock up to two more hero slots as you find them in the dungeon, with a total of 16 different heroes available to choose from. Resource managing is key in Dungeon of the Endless.
If you want strong characters, you'll need to build food modules,
if you want tons of laser cannons to stop wave upon wave of enemies, you will need machinary resources.
And if you want access to additional modules ranging from decoys, lasers, bombs, then you'll need to gather science resources.

(Here is the part where I explain how to play this game, making it even more confusing.)

reviewText:
Fun, simple, but very hard dungeon exploration/survival/tower defense game. You have maxium of 4 heroes that explore dungeon level by level, trying to find elevator to the next level. Dungeon is built out of rooms, and uou open up doors which represent turns. Each turn you gain resources that you use to build modules and towers, research new things, level up and heal heroes. While exploring, you encounter hordes of monsters spawning out of darkness, which will try to kill you and your core, which you need to protect to get out of the dungeon.

Like all Endless games, this game as well is meant to be replayed again and again, with different settings, like characters or core-mechanics that you unlock by playing the game.

For a casual scrub like me, the game is definitely too hard on easy difficulty, but challenging enough on Too Easy" difficulty.

reviewText:
This game is trash. The concept and game play are fantastic, but unfortunately there are more glitches than actual game play.

After playing, I have experienced numerous glitches. Almost 75% of games played had major glitches. The many annoying glitches are as follows.

On multiplayer:
Items often duplicate or disappear when trading.
Constant disconnects.

Single Player:
Save files corrupt constantly.
Heroes die randomly with no enemies around. (happened once)
Often times, icons displaying statuses wont appear (like the gear for operate skill).
Nodes that are fully lit, and should allow placement, sometimes get glitched so placement is impossible.
If the game closes at any time, EVER, expect to lose progress because of the developers stupid save-scumming prevention. Even last autosave gets lost.

Above all, the absolute worst part of this game is its saving mechanism. Too often, the game will not detect saves that are present. It will simply ignore them. The developer tried too hard to prevent save-scumming and, in the process, botched it up. It is very frustrating to have a great run and press the save and quit button, only to come back later and find no save. Sometimes after reinstalling the game it will magically reappear and sometimes not. Until the developer can fix the saving mechanism of the game so that it can be quit and actually save progress, I cannot recommend this game.

reviewText: I've played several games with my mates and we've had such a great time. Our enjoyment diminished quickly however, when we encountered the terrible issues in the multiplayer system Amplitude Studios have implemented. It's the only reason why I'm not recommending this game.\n\nThe rest of the game is just a blast to play, but is ruined by the fact that your progress can be ruined at any time after doing a run for over 3 hours. reviewText: I need to stop believing people when they tell me that there is such a thing as a good roguelike.  I bought this game on the strength of the combination of Roguelike / 4E / Tower Defense... except it's not.  It's just another terrible little roguelike, a sadistic RNG that takes the place of creative level design.  The concept is nice.  Open a door, explore your environment step by step, do some research, build defenses... die, lose everything.... Repeat?  Why?  I get the idea that the makers of DotE are confused by the concepts of TD and 4E games, both of which I love, and both of which are predicated on the idea of slow, steady, calculated improvement.  Every time you conquer a level in a TD, you unlock more and more of the game, your skills get better, you gain more towers, and you take on greater challenges.  In 4E, resource gathering and untilization, slowly expanding your sphere of influence... these take hours or days, and garner iterative improvement.  In DotE the floors just aren't big enough.  Your empire consists of a couple upgrades, maybe three or four production units total, and maybe a dozen turrets.  Upgrades you research on one floor and almost everything you built are lost when you move up a level and nothing is gained from game to game besides a slow, inevitable feeling of malaise at the realization you've wasted money on this.  I love hard games.  I love overcoming challenges, but I like to feel like I'm the master of my fate and the utter blithering randomness, the haha

Ditto Bridge and Chess.  Know what's simple? Hopscotch.  Simplicity means nothing if the core game itself isn't good.  DotE could be good

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic art direction - mediocre gameplay.

A game that (currently) isn't the sum of its parts. All the elements are there, apart from something compelling to do when you play it. The concept is original enough, but the execution is in turns tedious, repetitive and unfair. Playing simply involves repeating the same actions, stage after stage, and hoping the RNG doesn't screw you too badly.

Unlike true Rogue-likes such as FTL and Binding of Isaac, this is essentially a very pretty, but basic, tower defence game with occasional difficulty spikes, or loot drops, as its 'random' element. None of these are compelling like Spelunky's altars or shopkeepers, or FTL's story choices, but simple occasional resource gifts or monster waves.

The problem here is that it misjudges what makes tower defence fun - accurately managing those resources. By tying those into the RNG (level layout strongly dictates your defences and resource gathering) your strategy is always a slave to the RNG, and can often be ruined simply by an obnoxious layout simply starving you of resources, or forcing you to defend more points than is possible.

This makes the game a case of going through the motions, repeating an optimal strategy with little breathing room for experimentation, until you luck into a good run or are forced into an unfair loss. All 10 stages play exactly the same, but just get larger and contain more damaging enemies. Once you've finished stage 1, you've essentially seen the entire game.

A shame, as every other element is dripping with style and polish, and the mixture of TD, dungeon crawling and Rouge-like works as a proof of concept, but unfortunately all you get here is simply a marriage of extremely shallow reprentations of all three genres.

6/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR Great game, devoted devs, buy now if you want to shape the game and experience the development.
As of 0.6.1 i am enjoying this game thoroughly. There are enough characters and since adding 8 levels an indepth clear is currently around 3 hours of play. Though i have read aot of complaints and they fall into two categories too hard or no diversity.
In respect to difficulty there are currently two options, easy and too easy. As their name suggests  neither option is very difficult. However if you play this game and do not consider that is a combinations of many game types and aproach it as one you will lose fairly quickly. Also, aproaching each level with no forethought or strategy will cause a loss aswell. It is of course a strategy game so those who lack it will not suceed. Furthermore, the learning curve is fairly easy and once you get the hang of it is a blast.
In respect to a lack of diversity you have to remember this game is still in alpha. if you are buying a early access game looking for a full game experience then you will be dissapointed. The devs are pushing out consistent updates, much faster than alot of the other early access games on steam. They fix bugs very quickly and if a patch is game breaking they pull it so you can still play while they work on it. By buying the game now you can shape development by voting on their website.

The game itself is quite simple. There are currently 3 resources industry, science and food. Industry is for building modules and major modules help produce those three resources. Minor modules are turrets support turrets and defensive turrets. Science allows you to resource upgrades for your modules and new modules themselves. food allows you to recruit new heroes after your starting heroes, level up your heores(current max lvl 8 due to 8 Floors) and heal them during fights.
You use these resources to build a defense network so that when the exit of the lvl is found you can safely bring your crystal(the object that allows you to power rooms so you can build in them) to the next lvl. Each level gets increasingly difficult with new enemies and more rooms.
Heroes: Heroes come in all shapes in sizes and currently there are four stats, and five weapons types(currently 0.6.1). Stats are health,speed,damage and wit. Weapon types are sword, spear, pistol, machine gun, unarmed. health is how much life you start with and how much life you get every time you level up. Speed is movement speed. Wit is comparable to an intelligence stat but is mostly used for heroes you can operate major modules(Operating is to give a bonus to their production rate or bonus it gives) by increasing the operator bonus. Damage is the amount of damage you do. All of these stats scale when you level the heroe and different heroes are more proficient in different stats.There is no heroe that is useless all of them serve a specific purpose and you can win by using any combination of them.Also, there are armors and support items, most with comical names or premises.
Finally a great amount of thought has gone into this game from the item descriptions and the heroe backgrounds to the strategies that are available and to the details in each room. This ia a great product and i am highly anticipating the finished version.

Its amazing.
The levels are never the same , so you dont know if your find the door in the next room or 15 doors later.

you never get angry when you get killed you just start again.

reviewText:
Exactly what you want in a Roguelike -- Lots of depth.  Lots of variety.  Lots of strategy.  Very rewarding to play and master.
9 out of 10 (with the potential for 10/10 with further development which is in the pipeline)

Starts off very hard, but you always know why you died/failed.  As you learn how the game and characters work, the game gets much easier and starts to really shine.  If you're on the fence, get the basic 'Pixel Pack' - you don't get much with the upgrade to Crystal (one hero, one game mode).  I play on Linux under WINE with no major problems, although it's not supported.

Pros:
+ Great characterizations, diverse skills which dramatically change the game
+ Monsters which force you to change tactics floor-to-floor
+ Game modes, while a little thin, do offer a good dose of variety
+ Music/Sound is excellent.  even at 100+ hours in, the music is still a welcome addition.
+ Tactics and strategy matter - a lot!
+ Lots of replayability and more in the future thanks to continued development
+ Even if you're an expert, there's still a lot of challenge

Cons:
- Tower defense aspect is really a second fiddle to the heroes, especially in lower levels, mostly due to one enemy type (Zoners) destroying minor modules
- Multiplayer is still rough (but being improved patch by patch)
- The music in the first video is not in the game
- Interface could use a little work (health is hard to see, 'restore skill' is hidden, can't pin heroes to rooms)
- Characters sometimes don't attack/repair immediately (minor quibble, really)
- Crystal running is usually trivial

About the difficulty: it's hard, yes (and I like hard), but you get to the point where the balance flips and losing becomes a rarity.  It's still difficult and rewarding, but the heal mechanic means you can just overproduce food and heal all the time, so it's actually hard to lose outright.  Many of my first few losses were simply being to skimpy on healing; lesson learned...always top heroes off if you want them to live.

Other tips:
* take 30 minutes and read a guide or two; it'll save you a few failed runs.
* start on 'very easy'
* PAUSE. all the time. assess how the battle's going.  is one hero in trouble?  are enemies going a path you didn't anticipate?
* don't heavily invest in offense modules; your heroes should be doing most of the fighting
* change your strategy if you see Zoners (triangle guys which attack minor modules), Dozers (big rock guys which attack major modules), or Riders (can open doors). monsters are set per floor.  if you see one of the above, the level is going to be much, much harder
* Max is very, very good thanks to his ability to generate dust on door opens.  makes floors 8+ much easier.
* Controlling aggro is essential, although there are many ways to do it.  the easiest is with Skroig, the necrophage character, and his Red Plume skill - reset (on the character sheet) when necessary; it's cheaper than healing/rebuilding.
* Floors start at about 11 doors for level 1 and go to about 32 doors. generally, keep building resource generators until 2/3rds through. shoot for two operators at all times. make use of mechanical pals, when you'll be sure they pay off.
* when dust gets short, have one 'exploration' wing where only one room is lit for defenses (with a combat hero that can control aggro), and one 'production' wing where all rooms are lit.  only open more rooms on the 'production' wing when you have enough dust to light the room you're going to open.
* neurostun, tear gas, and biotransferrance are some of the best support modules
* research 'Shop's and put an Operator on any merchants you find post floor 7-8

reviewText: This game is the absolute perfect mix of Tower Defense, Strategy, and RPG, all mixed in with a bit of Beautiful Pixelated Graphics. The Gameplay is Smooth and Entertaining, Resource Management between you and your team is challenging, and Behind every door is the possibility of Life or Death.  This game could easily be played for hours with you and your 3 friends all shuffling around the rooms trying to not Screw up. In this game Teamwork and Communication is crutial and makes the game Entertaining. While you can play Single Player, I highly suggest buying this for you and a friend to play, it is about 10 times more fun with other people.  You have your 4 Resources, Food, Production (Which allows Building Defenses and Production Buildings), Science, And Dust.  Food Allows you to level up, buy items from vendors, heal in the middle of a turn, and even to hire new characters.  Science allows you to Research New Buildings and Building Upgrades, and also to occasionally buy items from vendors although it's more likely to see a vendor buying either Production or Food, And Dust allows you to power rooms for Defenses, Production, and (Most importantly) to stop Monsters from Spawning in a room. The Monsters are pretty Tough to say the least and can make you almost smash your keyboard into the wall which makes resource and power management more crucial to your sanity. To get through a Level you must find the exit and get both your Main Gem and your characters into the Exit Room. This game is Worth the Money and the developers are amazing for this game. If you have the money pick up a few copies for you and your friends

reviewText:
A fantastic combination of tower defense with rpg and randomized elements. Each new pod you unlock changes the feel and play of the game to a great degree, making multiple playthroughs worthwhile, challenging and fun. Highly recommended.

There is a definite learning curve, and it can take a few hours to get yourself going in a groove to get the feel for each unique escape pod's rules for success. The tutorial is lacking, but the guides aren't. If you're up for a challenge and the twoer defense and rogue like aspects are interesting to you, grab this.

BE WARNED: the rogue-like aspects can mean you hit a floor you will need to play perfectly to beat, and you can lose a lot of progress for making a bad gamble. [and to some degree, the game can bone you with a punishing floor and there isn't much you can do if you get no dust (a type of currency) for like 9 rooms straight].

reviewText:
The only question I have is why I can't murder other heroes to loot them. The rest of my questions have all been killed out of me.

I didn't think I'd like a roguelike this much. Maybe this and FTL have a secret hold on me. When it comes down to what you like about them, the challenge or the exploration, I think I like this game better as the challenge doesn't rely entirely on totallyrandom generation. Imagine if you could improve your ship in FTL without needingit all to come from shops or random encounters, but also gave you the options of directly influencing the parts of your ship with scrap, reinforcing the hull or weapons by themselves. That's what the heroesin this game fillthe gap on. Mixing it with tower defense makes this game engaging as you try tokeep heroes inbetween monsters and your crystal ala Dungeon Defenders, and executes it with the power sent to each grid. Managing these, your heroes and your defense network makes the game engaging.

I would like to see more ships added. I enjoythe fact you can have certain gains and deficits granted by each pod, but if the developer doesn't make some whacky options available, or powerful ones, then the gimmick is short lived. I may be the only one who wants to see strange and fantastic options anymore, though. The excitement of seeing the doors open (as this is a door opening simulator, not a monster defense game as one would assume) is sadly reduced once you've run the gambit of monsters. I would like to see more happen.

Gameplay: 9/10 Polished, well executed, and lacking in only the slightest of refinements. The stats lack descriptions and the tutorial hucks you in after a basic example.

Story: 7/10 Must unlockthe characters and have them gab at one another for the story, but then again, that isn't what you came to do in this game, was it?

Graphics: 8/10 Very pretty in game environments, monsters are varied but fit thesame subcategories, heroes continue to surpirse me in some ways. But the lit rooms sometimes offer little more than the dark ones did other than lack of gnawing death.

Sound 9/10: As with games of this nature, sound effects are re-used oftenbut it doesn't grate the ears. Music is appropriate, well done, and generally pleasing.

Overall: 9/10: Would open more doors.

Rogue Like Dungeon crawler.
You end up on this planet after your" (aka the ship you were on as staff or prisoner) prison ship got attacked and destroyed. Dont worry you managed to launch a escape pod and escape death... for now.
Your only option once landed with 2 survivors is to open the door out the unknown... with a minor hope of a ticket somewhere away from this dangerous place.

Economy is split between Four things.
Food to level and heal your heroes.
Science to remove cooldown on abilites or research new modules that will make your journey easier (to make it possible that you might survive without good luck or being veteran to the game)
building material (dont recall correct term) That you build modules that increases one of these three or many minor one with offensive defensive or boosts to the room you build them in.
And finally we have Dust... Your best friend. Without this materia darkness will consume the entire level. Also the merchants love Dust since it is also the currency in this game.
So will you spend some dust to buy a new weapon or armor? Or will you light another room so unknown lurkers cant spawn there to attack you that might occur when you open up yet another door into the unknown? The option is yours

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: This review is for the final patch prior to the full release of the game. There's currently no Coop mentioned, and I have not tried the ships / gametype variants so I will not mention either.

My GOTY candidate. There's a lot more here than what you see at first glance.

PROS:
- Hero choices make the game varied, and engaging.
- Gear and Builds become interesting and somewhat diverse (more on this later).
- Resource management is straightforward, and easy to grasp. Interesting decision on how you use your resources added in later patches.
- Level of difficulty is very high (this might be a con for some)
- Excellent art style.

CONS:
- RNG can definitely kill your run, hands down.
- Balance was lacking a bit. There were some OP builds which made the game easier, though some of these have been addressed in patches.
- The game expects you to learn its ins and outs via investing time. It's not very easy to pick up.
- Unlocking heroes can be fun, though once you get to the latter heroes to unlock, it feels like a time sink.

Overall:
Bottom line for me personally is that I really enjoy the depth of the game. It took me hours of fiddling around with what's possible, and strategizing and using tactics and a relatively high level of micromanagement to beat the game on its hardest difficulty. Though RNG can make this game a bit more tedious than I'd like, I stil find this a refreshing take on the genre (or mash of genre's in this case).

It's really the gameplay and the extreme level of dedication and understanding of the systems in the game that make this  extremely fullfilling to play. Few experiences have pushed me that close to the edge and I enjoyed every minute of it. There's definitely some downsides, but compared to most triple A releases this game packs a huge punch for the price. It does offer a large amount of replayability in the form of heroes, and playing to their strengths plus adjusting strategy to come up with new playstyles on the fly. You won't win on the first go, and chances are it will take you some time to even clear a few floors. But if you're like me, you'll really enjoy the experience.

Once CoOp is added, I'll be back in to spend some time trying to sync with my friends and beat the game for my 7th time.

reviewText:
Dungeon of the Endless is very hard to define in today standard of games.
The best way I found to define it is that it has an old-school soul: the art is great, the music is extremely fitting and the gameplay extremely innovative.
That being said, the game still has its down points, unbalance is one of them. (watch out for those jumping fat men, URGH I HATE THOSE GUYS *rage quits*)
Only being recently released as a 1.0 version, you can't really say the game's development is done. The devs are still working on new content and posting about it frequently.
Also, you might want to play it with your friends, and you can, with up to 4 of them over network.

tl;dr : Innovative game with plenty of eye-candy, really hard sometimes, has co-op.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With out a doubt one of the best games that I purchased this year.  It's a rogue-like and it can be hard and unforgiving at time but that makes it all the more sadistically fun.  The RPG elements including character leveling, equipment, and individual abilities unique to each hero, mesh well and ensures multiple playthroughs which can be very unique depending on which heros the player is using.  As your heros open doors of the dungeon they accumulate resouces which are used to build offencive and defensive turrets in rooms,  power rooms and constructed turrets or generators in rooms,  to level characters and to purchase turret and character upgrades and equipment.   The combination of managing all these elements might first sound complex  but the game does a great job at intragating all the features togather well in a way that makes sense and also makes you think tactically the further you get in the dungeon.
Though the game is stll in development  it  has been updated regularly in the six or so months that I have owned it and alot of new content has been added.  At my last playthrough there were eight levels to the dungeon implemented and over ten heros (though I have only unlocked 5 or so) with more being planned as the game is updated and gets closer to offical release.

After crashing on an unknown planet, Nurse Deena Ratchet and genetically engineered warrior Hikensha began working their way through the ship to hope for an escape. Along the way they recruited a young burglar named Golgy Phurtiver who, incidentally, thinks she's a spider of some sort.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR Great game, devoted devs, buy now if you want to shape the game and experience the development.
As of 0.6.1 i am enjoying this game thoroughly. There are enough characters and since adding 8 levels an indepth clear is currently around 3 hours of play. Though i have read aot of complaints and they fall into two categories too hard or no diversity.
In respect to difficulty there are currently two options, easy and too easy. As their name suggests  neither option is very difficult. However if you play this game and do not consider that is a combinations of many game types and aproach it as one you will lose fairly quickly. Also, aproaching each level with no forethought or strategy will cause a loss aswell. It is of course a strategy game so those who lack it will not suceed. Furthermore, the learning curve is fairly easy and once you get the hang of it is a blast.
In respect to a lack of diversity you have to remember this game is still in alpha. if you are buying a early access game looking for a full game experience then you will be dissapointed. The devs are pushing out consistent updates, much faster than alot of the other early access games on steam. They fix bugs very quickly and if a patch is game breaking they pull it so you can still play while they work on it. By buying the game now you can shape development by voting on their website.

The game itself is quite simple. There are currently 3 resources industry, science and food. Industry is for building modules and major modules help produce those three resources. Minor modules are turrets support turrets and defensive turrets. Science allows you to resource upgrades for your modules and new modules themselves. food allows you to recruit new heroes after your starting heroes, level up your heores(current max lvl 8 due to 8 Floors) and heal them during fights.
You use these resources to build a defense network so that when the exit of the lvl is found you can safely bring your crystal(the object that allows you to power rooms so you can build in them) to the next lvl. Each level gets increasingly difficult with new enemies and more rooms.
Heroes: Heroes come in all shapes in sizes and currently there are four stats, and five weapons types(currently 0.6.1). Stats are health,speed,damage and wit. Weapon types are sword, spear, pistol, machine gun, unarmed. health is how much life you start with and how much life you get every time you level up. Speed is movement speed. Wit is comparable to an intelligence stat but is mostly used for heroes you can operate major modules(Operating is to give a bonus to their production rate or bonus it gives) by increasing the operator bonus. Damage is the amount of damage you do. All of these stats scale when you level the heroe and different heroes are more proficient in different stats.There is no heroe that is useless all of them serve a specific purpose and you can win by using any combination of them.Also, there are armors and support items, most with comical names or premises.
Finally a great amount of thought has gone into this game from the item descriptions and the heroe backgrounds to the strategies that are available and to the details in each room. This ia a great product and i am highly anticipating the finished version.

reviewText:
An intriguing blend of tower defense, rts, and dungeon crawler, that suffers the foibles of all three.

The art style is crisp and reminiscent of FTL, while bringing tidbits of lore from the Endless Space universe. Meanwhile, its cast is relatively new, so there's no worries for those who aren't a big fan of the 4x game Dungeon of the Endless is deriving its lore from.

Gameplay largely functions in an RTS micromanagement style. Where in an RTS you may be controlling dozens of units in multiple control groups, Dungeon of the Endless plays in a more hero-themed style, controlling only up to four characters at a time. Multiplayer games allow players to reduce the number of units that must be micromanaged, and a four-man band can each have one player, allowing for very simple or very complex micro scenarios.

Main stumbling block of the game is the newly implemented multiplayer. Because turns are based on doors opened, and because certain things, say, research, demand a number of doors to complete--and because there are a limited number of doors in a floor, and increasing threats in deeper floors--playing with new players is an experience in frustration, as they will be compelled to progress turns through a desire for exploration--whereupon overwhelming numbers of enemies can spawn.

Additionally, DotE suffers from an overdependence on a turn-based resource pool, and thus the management of 'build orders'. While the build order/research dynamic works fine in an RTS, where you're in a technology arms race against an opponent in a sportlike setting, the opposite is the case in a team-based dungeon crawler. Since as many as four people can be in the same party, there's often a pressing urge to 'do' something, when the gameplay demands the players instead take their time and plan for the whole group. Depending on the player personalities, this can lead to an 'Armchair General' type of situation, where one player makes the decisions, while the rest either simply nod and follow along, or stand around waiting to defend against spawned monsters from unlit rooms. Not helped by this is an Operating" mechanic on many of the characters
date: which incentivizes players to hold their ground and utilize a resource building to produce extra resources
hoursPlayed: every move through a door is a collectively agreed-upon move for the team
voteText: or else resources dwindle
helpfulPercent: and monsters become overwhelming.\n\nSome of the spawning mechanics probably need a little tweaking. As much as a roguelike should encourage preparation

reviewText:
This is a game that tries to mix some unusual set of mechanics into one game. I used to play this during early access and I could see the potential back then but it was far from balanced; it had one particular winning strategy that rendered most of the mechanisms in the game pointless.

I'm happy to say that these days are long gone, the final version of Dungeon of the Endless is a very successful experimentation in game design that will keep you entertained exploring different strategies you never thought you'd use together in the same game.

There's a lot of luck involved though, keep that in mind if that's not your thing. But luck is a factor in many games considered good, specially in rogue-likes. In these games the fun is like a good game of cards, you develop skills as you play the game over and over again until you know the best strategies for the hand you were given. And there are many cards and possibilities in Dungeon of the Endless. I totally recommend it.

reviewText: Rogue-like, ressources gathering, rpg elementa, hero control, micromanagement, tactical combat, tower defense.. arrg thats not even it, lets make this simpler.. You control heroes and progress through a dungeon of your choice, trying to reach the exit.\nOn your way you will build modules to gather ressources to research new tech, level up/heal your hero and build defensive and offensive modules. Even on the easier difficulty the game will get harder and harder as you go. it can become quite addictive. The hero selection allows you to customise and build a team around what you need/prefer and the various 'gamemodes' represnted by the various escape pods, add a few different games options. The game is solid in execution and gameplay. Id think it would end up being too short, but as you go, you will play more carefully and take your time to progress, i ended up playing over 80h (i usualy get bored of most games rather fast). I did not touch the multiplayer yet so i cannot coment on it, but there is also that option.

reviewText: It's an apt testimony to the skill and passion of the Amplitude folks that Dungeon of the Endless has become my go-to timewaster. The premise is simple: Your prison ship's been attacked and you've crash-landed on an uncharted planet. You and your motley band of inmates, ship staff and exotic natives must navigate the twelve floors of the mysterious dungeon you've found yourself in by finding the elevator on each floor and using the crystal" generator from your escape pod to power it and move to the next level up. That crystal is also needed to power the rooms of the dungeon
date: providing a variety of resources conducive to your survival
recommended: but it is limited by its supply of "dust"
hoursPlayed: and each room left unpowered has a chance to spawn a wave of hostile fauna whenever you open a new door on that floor.\n\nThe gameplay is an elegant combination of roguelike
voteText: tower defence and classic RPG mechanics. It's both accessible and challenging

Managing your heroes is therefore crucial to success.\n\nThe understated soundtrack and the pseudo-pixellated

column22: best-buddy team; are experiences that remain with you long after their runs have ended. Some combinations of characters even have unique backstories of their own

reviewText:
Went into this game blind, Saw it was free for a period and just went at it.

At first, I did not like it, it felt....awkward. The gameplay was odd, and the way your interface worked felt clunky. But then, after giving it time I got used to it, everything fell into place and I was able to start enjoying the game.

After my initial 10 failed runs on Single Player and a few Character Unlocks, I really picked up the game and got into it, so I decided to try out multiplayer, that part of the game wasnt so much fun.  Every game I got into was full of Zerg Rushers, Leeroy Jenkin's w/e you want to call them. I ended up just ditching two of the players in my game so my friend and I could dual character, in which case we did much better than with others.

The Game has a slight learning curve but once you get it down, be prepared for hours of fun. My only gripe is that the producers gave perm access to a different title of theirs instead of this.

After crashing on an unknown planet, Nurse Deena Ratchet and genetically engineered warrior Hikensha began working their way through the ship to hope for an escape. Along the way they recruited a young burglar named Golgy Phurtiver who, incidentally, thinks she's a spider of some sort.

Things were going relatively well - Nurse Ratchet discovered a woman in stasis, who was revealed to be a bounty hunter named Sara Numas. They did not know that they were effectively recruiting Hikensha's replacement, however, who died tried to defend another survivor from the alien natives.

The party marched upwards, exploring for every resource they could. Another survivor was revived from stasis, but the mercenary (who dubbed himself Butcher") was eviscerated by what can only presumed to be giant mutant slugs when making casual conversation with a merchant.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dungeon of the Endless is an interesting new title by Amplitude Studios currently in Alpha development which spans several popular genres.

For my full featured review with pictures and videos coming soon please visit http://progamereviews.com/review/dungeon-endless/

You begin Dungeon of the Endless with two hero characters and a crystal in a small escape pod. The basic premise of the game is to explore each dungeon and find the exit. Each dungeon is comprised of interconnected randomly generated rooms. Many of these rooms contain mobs of monsters that attempt to end your game by either killing your heroes or your crystal. As you explore the dungeon's rooms you acquire resources and have the ability use these resources to deploy defenses. Game play is actually a hybrid of real time and turn based strategy in that you have the ability to pause live game play and issue commands if you so desire. The game can also be played in real time mode exclusively. Once the exit is located, your job is to transport the crystal safely there. If you make it you win the round and move on to the next level. If your heroes die, you lose. If your crystal’s dust level (essentially health, power and currency all in one) falls to zero, you lose. Piece of cake right? WRONG.

Dungeon of the Endless has a lot of things going on. At its heart, it is a rouge like (hate that term) dungeon crawler. You explore a procedurally generated environment with a small group of  playable heroes. What that means is this: the dungeons and encounters are never exactly the same. Sure you’ll see similarities, but by and large the environments will never be exactly alike. Additionally, your band of motley heroes isn’t invincible. Once they die, they’re dead… FOREVER. Kiss all that experience and loot goodbye! Rogue like game play; check.

So what else does the game offer? How about some resource management? In Dungeon of the Endless your success or failure is largely linked to your resource acquisition and management. There are four main resources to worry about: Dust (no you can't snort it), Industry, Food and Science. Every time you open a room you receive an amount of each resource except dust. Additionally, you can deploy resource modules in powered rooms (more on that later) that add a modifier to the amount of a particular resources obtained when subsequent doors are opened. For example, an Industry module will provide additional industry every time you open a new door. Heroes with the required skill can even operate the module and provide an additional, additional bonus to the resources. Phew, that sounds complicated. Of note here is that extra resources, except dust, are carried over to the next dungeon.

Dungeon of the Endless also has Role Playing and Character Progression aspects. Even though the game features permadeath you have the ability to level up your hero's and outfit them with gear discovered in dungeons. Your heroes have stats which increase as their levels increase. In addition, as you level up your heroes they gain access to special combat skills.

But wait, there's more...

Dungeon of the Endless also offers tower defense like game play. As you explore each dungeon level you open up" additional parts of the map. Each new room traversed is dark
date: which means it is currently not powered. These darkened rooms serve as spawn points for mobs of monsters which attack in waves and make a beeline toward your crystal. How do you stop these waves of monsters you ask? Well
recommended: you power some of these dark rooms with part of your limited supply of dust. Once powered
hoursPlayed: you then use your Industry resource to build defenses. As waves of enemies appear
voteText: your smartly placed defenses and heroes take them out. Sounds kinda tower defense like huh.\n\nOne of Amplitude Studios goals is community involvement. Amplitude wants the players to take an active part in the game's development and it is facilitating this by utilizing a system called GAMES2GETHER . One of the biggest reasons to play an early access game is to participate in the evolution of a game. Plenty of Steam early access games claim to use player feedback to help shape the final product into what the community wants... and then promptly don't. Amplitude appears to actually be following through with it. By utilizing it's G2G Votes system
helpfulPercent: the community has the ability to vote on art and game design decisions. For example
votesHelpful: the current vote is for creating a new playable character. There is also a standard forum where players can follow the games development and post their questions and comments. The jury is still out on how much the community will drive development however so we'll have to monitor the process and see how it goes.\n\nLike every other game out there
votesTotal: Dungeon of the Endless is not perfect. I'll cover what I feel are weak points for the game first. The game needs a lot more explanation. This is a reasonably complex game and the current tutorial slides just don't cut it. I found myself with more questions than answers after the tutorial and had to stumble into them myself. A proper tutorial level guiding the player through the games nuisances would help to acclimate players better. As this is just the alpha stage
votesFunny: i'm sure the developers will address this in the near future. The graphics are basic. Again
commentsCount: this is by design but worth noting anyway.\n\nAnother issue is repetitiveness. Although the levels are procedurally generated they all look and feel essentially the same. This in addition to the fact that the basic game play remains the same can make the game feel a bit tedious after a while.  Is there an end to the game or is it truly endless? I don't actually know the answer to that question. But if the game had milestones or varied locations to make you feel like your progressing it might help. Its worth noting that in general I usually don't play rogue like games specifically for this reason. As an old school RPG and MMORPG player

I like to feel that i'm making progress towards a larger goal and I just didn't feel it with this game.\n\nAll that being said

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(As of version Alpha 0.2.1) I picked up this game on a whim - it had the specs: indie, sci-fi, strategy, and fun art-direction.

When I first picked it up, only the bare mechanics were in place. You took your heroes from room to room and tried to fight back the hordes going after your crystal. It was compelling then and with the features they continue to add, the game keeps getting more addictive.

The idea is that a prison space ship crashes on an unknown planet. You need to direct your 'heroes' (guards and/or prisoners) to find the exit of the dungeon that they're stuck in. Each room will have doors. Every time you open a door you discover a new room which may have an item, a resource, or monsters. As you open more doors, you collect resourses and power which you can use to power/light-up rooms. Monsters will not appear in powered rooms while they could potentially show up in un-powered rooms.

There are two phases to each level. The first phase is strategic exploration and tower defence: you can install turrets in your powered rooms to help your heroes fight the monsters. The second phase requires you to bring your crystal to the exit. It's a bit of a mad dash to the finish line. As you leave a room with the crystal, that room loses it's power supply. The two phases keep the levels fresh and keeps you planning ahead.

If you enjoy strategy games, tower defence games, sci-fi, indie, elements of RPG, or like good pixel art then this game is for you! Even better, as they're still developing the game, more an more features are being added!

At this Alfa stage (0.1.0) the game has 3 levels and many of the more interesting things like abilities/science are not yet implemented.

reviewText: I picked this up in a pack along with Endless Legend and Space because I wanted to get into a new 4x game. This game wasn't on my radar before and I didn't really expect anything from it. However what I found was a surprisingly addictive roguelike that borrowed elements from a dozen other genres put together into a deceptively complex whole. I feel like they'd work well in a more fully fleshed out RPG setting with expanded mechanics.\n\nIt would be nice if there was some kind of persistence between tries outside of which heroes you have unlocked to start with as I do feel that is a barrier to replayability currently. reviewText:
This game is awesome! It kind of reminds me of that Space Hulk game on 3DO. I did a quick intro video for my dad, but anyone else can take a look to see what it's like. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=370775353

You control up to 4 heroes with different skillsets that you can level up and equip with items you find in chests or from merchants. The goal is to find the elevator exit for each randomly generated floor, then grab your crystal and high tail it to the exit before the horde of aliens murder you.

There's also a tower defense and resource management aspect to the game. You can plop down some mini turrets that either damage/debuff enemies, or buff your heroes. Opening a door to a different room is considered a turn, which grants you more resources, but also has a chance to spawn waves of enemies.

There's a lot more to the game, but I recommend not looking at any guides since most of the fun comes from honing your strategy (dying over and over again) and finding out which playstyle works for you!

Con:
I would hold off on multiplayer until a save function is implemented. It looks like the developers are really responsive to the community, so it shouldn't be long =]. In the meantime, have fun in single player, still definitely worth the money.

reviewText: I love this game. It combines the idea of a tower defence with the sharpness of a rogue-like dungeon crawler, with intuitive and surprising systems. As usual with Amplitude, I suffer from 'one more turn' syndrome every time I play this game. It is harder and shorter than a 4x, but keeps me on my toes all throught the game, unlike in a 4x where one starts knowing noone, this game has enemies that scale, change and destroy constantly, from suicide bomb-bugs to wizards to crystaline bohemoths to weird two-legged wolf-like things. The multiplayer is slightly unintuitive, but very enjoyable all the same.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here's my elevator pitch for Dungeon of Endless:

It's a rogue-like
date:
tower defense game with Left 4 Dead finales thrown in."

And it truly is an amagame of these things. It's like an rogue-like RPG in that you're exploring a randomly-generated dungeon and dealing with the enemies and other things you encounter there.

The tower-defense element pulls heavily from real-time strategy and role-playing elements. There's a pretty meaty three-resource system that you engage. You build machines to generate more of the resources then use those resources to build all kinds of offensive and defensive weapons or to level up your heroes (each with their own unqiue attributes
recommended: powers and weapons to equip).\n\nEvery time you open a door in the dungeon your machines produce the goods. There's also a chance of enemy waves spawning -- that's where the tower defense comes in. You need to build defenses to prevent them from running roughshod over your stuff (and eventually destroying your precious energy crystal). Smart
hoursPlayed: strategic exploration plays a big role here
voteText:
creating choke points and making sure that enemies don't swarm you all at once is key to survival.

Once you find the exit to the dungeon floor there's a final event where you must manually carry your power crystal from the start of the dungeon to the exit -- all the while fending off enemy's. That's where the Left 4 Dead allusion comes into play. These final runs can go horribly if you haven't powered and defended the path.

Since I've been playing there's been constant adjustment to the economy and difficulty of the game -- this is the kind of fine tuning you want from a game that's in Alpha. But throughout I've had fun playing the game. Even when the tuning made the game insanely hard. Even when the game is broken Dungeon of Endless is fun."

reviewText: This clever, nicely-paced game isn't quite FTL, but it's worth mentiong in the same sentence. FTL's basic gameplay is quite repetitive, but there are interesting choices to be made at the strategic level, as you find out what modules are on offer.  DOTE's basic gameplay has a fair amount of variation, but the number of viable strategies feels a lot more limited.  There's definitely a real learning curve, and unlocking character stories is quite satisfying.  However, DOTE feels much more like a series of tactical and operational puzzles than it gives a feeling of strategy.  I may be saying that because I haven't worked out the tactical puzzles yet (and am therefore blind to strategy) but there's a strong feeling of 'starting again' with each new floor that drains my sense of satisfaction and progression.\n\nIf you like exploring mazes and unlocking things, you'll get a ton of enjoyment out of DOTE.  That's not quite my thing, but I still enjoyed it for quite a few hours.

reviewText:
An intriguing blend of tower defense, rts, and dungeon crawler, that suffers the foibles of all three.

The art style is crisp and reminiscent of FTL, while bringing tidbits of lore from the Endless Space universe. Meanwhile, its cast is relatively new, so there's no worries for those who aren't a big fan of the 4x game Dungeon of the Endless is deriving its lore from.

Gameplay largely functions in an RTS micromanagement style. Where in an RTS you may be controlling dozens of units in multiple control groups, Dungeon of the Endless plays in a more hero-themed style, controlling only up to four characters at a time. Multiplayer games allow players to reduce the number of units that must be micromanaged, and a four-man band can each have one player, allowing for very simple or very complex micro scenarios.

Main stumbling block of the game is the newly implemented multiplayer. Because turns are based on doors opened, and because certain things, say, research, demand a number of doors to complete--and because there are a limited number of doors in a floor, and increasing threats in deeper floors--playing with new players is an experience in frustration, as they will be compelled to progress turns through a desire for exploration--whereupon overwhelming numbers of enemies can spawn.

Additionally, DotE suffers from an overdependence on a turn-based resource pool, and thus the management of 'build orders'. While the build order/research dynamic works fine in an RTS, where you're in a technology arms race against an opponent in a sportlike setting, the opposite is the case in a team-based dungeon crawler. Since as many as four people can be in the same party, there's often a pressing urge to 'do' something, when the gameplay demands the players instead take their time and plan for the whole group. Depending on the player personalities, this can lead to an 'Armchair General' type of situation, where one player makes the decisions, while the rest either simply nod and follow along, or stand around waiting to defend against spawned monsters from unlit rooms. Not helped by this is an Operating" mechanic on many of the characters
date: which incentivizes players to hold their ground and utilize a resource building to produce extra resources
hoursPlayed: every move through a door is a collectively agreed-upon move for the team
voteText: or else resources dwindle
helpfulPercent: and monsters become overwhelming.\n\nSome of the spawning mechanics probably need a little tweaking. As much as a roguelike should encourage preparation
